column6: yanjunchi}@sjtu.edu.cn  ABSTRACT  Graph matching aims to establishing node-wise correspondence between two graphs
column7: which is a classic combinatorial problem and in general NP-complete.

column2: deep graph matching methods start to resort to deep networks to achieve unprecedented matching accuracy.

this paper makes two complementary contributions which can also be reused as plugin in existing works: i) a novel node and edge embedding strategy which stimulates the multi- head strategy in attention models and allows the information in each channel to be merged independently.
only node embedding is accounted in pre- vious works; ii) a general masking mechanism over the loss function is devised to improve the smoothness of objective learning for graph matching.
it dynamically constructs a structured and sparsely connected layer
column3: taking into account the most contributing matching pairs as hard attention.

column2: and can also improve state-of-the-art methods as plugin
column3: regarding with matching accuracy on three public benchmarks.

column1: Edges can carry informative multi-dimensional attributes (namely weights) which are fundamental to graph matching.
However existing embed- ding based graph matching methods (Wang et al
column2: 2019; Xu et al
column3: 2019) are focused on the explicit modeling of node level features
column4: whereby the edges are only used as topological node connection for message passing in GCN.

column2: edge attributes are neither well modeled in the embedding-free model  since the edge information is derived from the concatena- tion of node features.
there is no deep graph matching method explicitly incorporating edge attributes.
edge attributes e.g. length and orientation are widely used in traditional graph matching models (Cho et al
column3: 2010; Yan et al
column4: 2015; Yu et al
column5: 2018) for constructing the affinity matrix K. Such a gap shall be filled in the deep graph matching pipeline.

column1: Another important consideration refers to the design of loss function.

There are mainly two forms in existing deep graph matching works: i) displacement loss  similar to the use in optical Ô¨Çow estimation ; ii) the so-called permutation loss  involving iterative Sinkhorn procedure followed by a cross-entropy loss.
Results in  show the latter is an effective improvement against the former regression based loss.

column2: we argue that the continuous Sinkhorn procedure (in training stage) is yet an unnatural approximation to Hungarian sampling (in testing stage) for discretization.

column1: If the network is equipped with a continuous loss function (e.g. cross-entropy)
column2: we argue that the training process will make a great ‚Äúmeaningless effort‚Äù to enforce some network output digits of the final matching matrix into binary and neglect the resting digits which might have notable impact on accuracy.

column1: This paper strikes an endeavor on the above two gaps and makes the following main contributions:  i) We propose a new approach for edge embedding via channel-wise operation
column2: namely channel- independent embedding (CIE).

column1: The hope is to effectively explore the edge attribute and simulate the multi-head strategy in attention models (VeliÀáckovi¬¥c et al
column2: 2018) by decoupling the calculations parallel and orthogonal to channel direction.
edge attribute information has not been consid- ered in existing embedding based graph matching methods (Wang et al
column3: 2019; Xu et al

column1: ii) We devise a new mechanism to adjust the loss function based on the Hungarian method which is widely used for linear assignment problem
column2: as termed by Hungarian attention.

column1: It resorts to dynami- cally generating sparse matching mask according to Hungarian sampling during training
column2: rather than approximating Hungarian sampling with a differentiable function.
the Hungarian attention introduces higher smoothness against traditional loss functions to ease the training.

column1: iii) The empirical results on three public benchmarks shows that the two proposed techniques are orthogonal and beneficial to existing techniques.

column2: on the one hand
column3: our CIE module can effectively boost the accuracy by exploring the edge attributes which otherwise are not consid- ered in state-of-the-art deep graph matching methods; on the other hand
column4: our Hungarian attention mechanism also shows generality and it is complementary to existing graph matching loss.

5 CONCLUSION  We have presented a novel and effective approach for learning based graph matching.

column2: the novelty of our method partially lies in the development of the Hungarian attention
column3: which in- trinsically adapts the matching problem.

column1: It is further observed from the experiments that Hungarian attention can improve several matching-oriented loss functions
column2: which might bring about potential for a series of combinatorial problems.
we also devise the channel independent embedding (CIE) technique for deep graph matching
column3: which decouples the basic merging opera- tions and is shown robust in learning effective graph representation.

column1: Extensive experimental results on multiple matching benchmarks show the leading performance of our solver
column2: and highlight the orthogonal contribution of the two proposed components on top of existing techniques.
